newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ SPORT - Rowing investigates Olympic failures.
newsitem.headline: NZ SPORT - Rowing investigates Olympic failures.

text.p: CHRISTCHURCH, Sept 23 - Rowing New Zealand (RNZ) boss Mike Stanley has called for an investigation into the failure of two crews at the Olympic Games in Atlanta last month, NZPA reported on Monday.
The men's coxless four and the lightweight double sculls were eliminated in the repechages at Atlanta after being rated possible medal chances.
"Few could have picked that both crews would have been so conspicuously off the pace," chief executive Stanley said in RNZ's annual report released today.
Stanley said the disappointment among the crews was tangible and equalled their dismay at performing so poorly.
"Their performance requires thorough examination," he said.
RNZ will discuss the unsatisfactory performance of some of the Olympic crews at the 109th annual meeting in Christchurch on Saturday.
Stanley also criticised television stations for exploiting the disappointment of scullers Brenda Lawson and Philippa Baker after they finished last in their Olympic final at Lake Lanier.
Television found a way to tarnish their image as truly great champions, he said.
"They (Baker and Lawson) knew it was their last shot at an Olympic title and probably their last row together. It hurt."
Despite comprehensive funding and extensive preparation for the Olympics, New Zealand's best effort on the water was a fifth in the coxless pair.
David Schaper and Toni Dunlop had only six weeks together to pull off a major surprise of the Olympics by coming from nowhere to finish fifth in the final.
Saturday's meeting will outline where New Zealand rowing is heading in the next four years to the Sydney Olympics.
Questions have been be asked whether New Zealand might have fared better in Atlanta by sending fewer crews with more funding and resources.
Of the five Kiwi boats entered in the Olympic regatta, only two made the medal finals.
The Sports Foundation granted rowing $186,000 this year but the sport is on notice that the present level of funding is dependent on world championship and Olympic gold medals being won.
RNZ will further review its operations and future plans at a special meeting on November 2.
